moves.2... g6 3. e4: I'll give this a "?" because it just loses a pawn.
moves.3... fxe4 4. Ng5: putting the knight on a good square. However the gambit with "e4" is usually considered better in this line: d4 f5,e4 fxe4, Nc3 Nf6,Bg5. There is a trap here if black tries to hold teh pawn with "d5". Can you find it? Answer next.
moves.4... Nf6: Defending the pawn. (The answer is Bxf6 exf6, Qh5  g6 and Qxd5 ;white has regained the pawn and will win another, putting them a clear pawn up.)
moves.5... d5: This works now because the Bishop can no longer go to g5.
moves.6. Bf4: Keeping up the development but it's hard to belive its worth a whole pawn.
moves.6... c6: Fortifying the centre and also keeping out ideas of Nb5.
moves.7. Qe2: This is preparation for castling, although Qd2 may be better as it dosnt block the Bishop on f1.
moves.7... Bg7 8. O-O-O h6: Forcing the active piece to retreat, or else to lose material.
moves.9. Nxd5: This is also a "?". The sacrifice was never going to work but its hard to see a good plan. Nh3 would still have been best though.
moves.10. Qb5+: It may look menacing, but it really has no effect.
moves.11. Be5: White is giving his pieces up for nothing.
moves.12. Bxf6 Bxf6 13. f3: The rest of the game hardly need notation.
Building up pressure against the king.
moves.17. c3 Qd6 18. f4 gxf4 19. Qf3 Nxd4: Winning a pawn due to the pin on the c file.
moves.20. Qf2 Nc2 21. Bd3 Bxd3 22. Rxd3 Ne3 23: Almost all blacks pieces are aiming towards the white king.
moves.23... Kf7: This calm move ensures that white cannot create threats against the king. The g pawn can be defended easily and black ca proceed with his attack.
